description: Bikeways data with manually verified (Google Street View/Earth and Web Search) painted lanes and cycle tracks for Calgary, Canada
notes: Originally downloaded on January 2023 from bikeways data at https://data.calgary.ca/Transportation-Transit/Calgary-Bikeways/yigb-2xmq, Updated on October 1 2024 from https://github.com/rrwen/recovr-infracycle/blob/main/data/calgary-bikeways-preprocess-v2.geojson to include years for install/upgrade dates with no years (see https://github.com/rrwen/recovr-eval/blob/main/src/archive/calgary-bikeways-2024-10-01.R), Updated on September 30 2024 to verify 4 additional segments, Updated on October 27 2024 to fill in missing types with existing years and vice versa, Updated on December 16 2024 to add final type and year columns

notes: Originally downloaded on January 2023 from bikeways data at https://open.toronto.ca/dataset/cycling-network/, Updated on October 27 2024 to fill in missing types with existing years and vice versa, Updated on December 16 2024 to add final type and year columns

description: KSI (1980-2024) data from the City of Toronto (David McElroy <David.McElroy@toronto.ca>) for Toronto, Ontario
notes: Documentation available at docs/tps-data-doc-2024-01-10.pdf (pages 12-14), Open Government Licence – Ontario, Retrieved from David as previous data from Toronto Police Services were missing about 26% of the ACCNUM

description:
The verification dates manually entered for the cycling infrastructure data were unstructured and do not follow a structured format suitable for analysis.
 
Nevan Opp nevanopp@cmail.carleton.ca went through the dates in Google Sheets, interpreted them, and formatted them into structured dates, while Richard Wen richard.wen@utoronto.ca updated and fixed errors as needed.

These structured dates can then be joined back to the unstructured dates to include higher resolution temporal data to the cycling infrastructure install and upgrade dates.
Data used for staggered interventions model with no control groups. Specifications from Brice Batomen Kuimi brice.kuimi@utoronto.ca.
Linear features representing streets, walkways, rivers, railways, highways and administrative boundaries within the City of Toronto.

Road segments representing existing cycling network across the City of Toronto, including both shared and dedicated bikeways of the following types: cycle tracks, bicycle lanes (including buffered bike lanes and contra-flow bike lanes), neighbourhood routes with sharrows (including wayfinding sharrows), multi-use trails (including off-road and in-boulevard), as well as signed cycling routes.
Geographical administrative boundary of the City of Toronto.
